utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: It’s way too fast.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: Felt good.

utterance.speaker: Choreographer
utterance.content: If we could clear the stage quickly, please.

utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: Maury, it’s too fast.

utterance.speaker: Maury
utterance.content: It’s exactly the same.

utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: Then slow it down.

utterance.speaker: Choreographer
utterance.content: Everything all right, Jeremy?

utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: Sure. Ready when you are.

utterance.speaker: Choreographer
utterance.content: From the allegro, please.

utterance.speaker: Woman
utterance.content: What’s his problem?

utterance.speaker: Choreographer
utterance.content: His back’s not 100%.

utterance.speaker: Female Staff Member
utterance.content: He can’t talk to the conductor like that.

utterance.speaker: Choreographer
utterance.content: No, he can’t. She could.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: You okay with the lift?

utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: Fine, unless you mess up the timing.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: My timing is perfect.

utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: It was last night.

utterance.speaker: Female Staff Member
utterance.content: Moment of truth.

utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: Ahhhhhh!

utterance.speaker: Male Staff Member
utterance.content: Damn it!

utterance.speaker: Manager
utterance.content: Penelope, are you all right?

utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: She can’t breathe. Call a doctor.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Are you going to ignore me all day, again? I help you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You tried to kill Chase.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Doing what you wanted. That’s all, boss. I exist.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, you don’t. I acknowledge my subconscious exists. Now go away.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Saying it is one thing, living it is another. You’re not rational. Not completely.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Put the phone on the receiver, send the hookers home and get dressed. We’ve got a case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m taking a personal day.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Twenty-one year old star of the New York Ballet collapsed on stage.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I love ballet but, as someone may have mentioned, I’m taking a personal day.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Cuddy said get your ass in or you’re fired.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: She’s not gonna fire you? If you don’t go to work?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Okay.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: How long do you figure until I just… disappear?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hold on.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No tumors or punctures in the lungs. No bruising. No sign of trauma. No STDs.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: And supplemental oxygen’s only gotten her saturation level to 60. Lungs keep collapsing despite a chest tube.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: ER ruled out the obvious. White count and temp are normal so no pneumonia.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Coffee’s burnt. Thirteen’s wearing cherry-flavored lip gloss. Foreman’s staring at you. Any of that helpful?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: STD?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We just said the tests were negative. You think we should…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: She’s a dancer. What about dehydration?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What about a pulmonary contusion?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: CT showed no inflammation on the lungs.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: What about dehydration?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: B.U.N. and creatinine are elevated but within range…

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Hey. I’m just the irrational part of your brain but elevated means high, right? Dehydration could hide an infection.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Dehydration could hide an infection. Go treat her for the obvious. IV fluids and antibiotics for the pneumonia.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: We’re like Magic and Kareem.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Mr. Pietramala, you have kidney cancer.

utterance.speaker: Pietramala
utterance.content: Wow. Is that a bad one? I mean, they’re all bad, but…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: The door was closed for a reason.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Well, now it’s open for a reason. We need to talk.

utterance.speaker: Pietramala
utterance.content: He just told me I have kidney cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then you’ll obviously need a moment to process.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m hallucinating.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m… I’ll be right back.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need you to sit in on my differentials, double-check everything I do.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You can’t treat patients.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s gotta be sleep apnea. I get a good night’s sleep and I still feel exhausted. Lack of delta sleep can lead to hallucinations.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Do you have any other neurological symptoms?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t think so.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Aphasia?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Memory loss?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nope.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Irritability?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah! That one!

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Don’t deflect. He cares about you. You care about him. Tell him you…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You shouldn’t be practicing. At least…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Enough! Don’t give me the look. I told you I was hallucinating.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Who were you talking to?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Someone who’s not actually here. Beyond that seems irrelevant.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Your mind made a choice. It means something.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: You know he’s just going to keep asking.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kutner.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Good choice. He feels bad.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You gonna help me or not?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I could eat from this place seven days a week.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We practically do.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You can order tomorrow night. Do you want some wine?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: No, thanks. I have my husband’s sperm.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Your dead husband’s?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: We froze it when he got diagnosed.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And you kept it? All this time?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I used to think if I didn’t find anyone, then…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: You found someone.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I know. But…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: What if it goes wrong? What if I turn out to be a radical anarchist with a secret family and that I age backwards?

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Nobody plans on getting divorced. I didn’t plan on my husband dying, but he did.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: So you’re saying you want a prenup, in liquid form.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: What if it’s not sleep apnea? Trauma from your motorcycle accident? Vicodin abuse? You need to be admitted.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: I know you’re wrong about sleep apnea which means you know you’re wrong about sleep apnea. You’re scared. Tell him you’re scared.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can’t sleep with you here.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Did it work?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do you see someone standing beside me?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then, no.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: So, what’s next on your list of things it’s not.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Patient’s not responding to the antibiotics. Still can’t breathe.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So run a test to confirm it’s pneumonia.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We can’t do a bronc because her lungs are still collapsed.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Trans-tracheal aspiration.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s basically water boarding.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It is pretty radical.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It’s a great idea!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Regular radical, me radical or me out of my mind radical?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Somewhere between regular and you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So what’s the problem?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Everything okay?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. Our patient can’t breathe. Either do the test or come up with a better one. So, we’re down to infection, trauma, MS, schizophrenia, pills.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Schizophrenia usually manifests younger.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s why it’s further down the list. We can confirm an infection with a simple blood test.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: An infection can be treated. Cured. Means you still got a job. Means you still got a life. Doesn’t make it a better idea, just a nicer one. This the rational you talking?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can’t do this on my own.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: When we inject the water it’s going to feel like you’re drowning, but it will be over in a few seconds.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: Then it will be better?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: A little.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Hold her shoulders down a little. Ready? You’re doing great. Here comes the liquid. Taub.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I slipped. Oh, no.

utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Her skin came off.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Her skin is sloughing off faster than we can replace it with the artificial skin.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Could be autoimmune.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: The ANA was negative.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Focus on the lungs.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You want us to ignore the fact that she’s lost 80% of her skin?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We know it’s not lung cancer. It could be a liver tumor, eats through to the lungs. Get an ultrasound of her liver. If you find masses, get a biopsy.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We can’t just ignore the skin. It’s obviously the most significant and dangerous symptom right now.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t think it is a symptom. I think we caused it.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: By doing what?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I prescribed antibiotics.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Toxic epidermal necrolysis. That’s a one in a million reaction.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah, well, maybe this is the one. Get swabs of her old skin to confirm.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Where the hell were you?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I do have a practice.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ballerina has toxic epidermal necrolysis.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Are you sure?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: About to be.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I feel guilty.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You didn’t do anything wrong. You prescribed antibiotics. Any other doctor would have done the exact same thing.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Any other doctor? Words can hurt, you know.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have no reason to feel guilty. It doesn’t make any sense. Unless there’s something wrong in the limbic area of my brain.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Guilt as a symptom?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s consistent with MS. And, since the blood tests were negative… I have to apologize. If I feel better then you’re right, I was feeling an emotion. If I feel nothing, it means my limbic brain is shot.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m Doctor House. Anyone explain to you your status?

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: They found a mass in my liver. Cancer.

utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: They said that they think they can treat it and that the skin is starting to take.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: I’ll be able to dance again.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: She’s half dead and she’s wondering if she’ll ever plie again? Healthy priorities. Let the mocking begin.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m sorry. I treated you for an infection before confirming that you had one. That’s why you lost your skin. I know you’re in pain. I know that I caused it. I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Very nice.

utterance.speaker: Jeremy
utterance.content: Thank you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Maybe you didn’t mean it.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I meant it. Did you do a liver biopsy to confirm?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Couldn’t. The artificial skin was too thin. She’d bleed out. Why were you talking to the patient?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I think skinless women are hot. Do a trans-jugular liver biopsy. If she bleeds, at least it stays in her veins.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Did you just check with Wilson again?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No. I felt nothing. It’s MS.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Apologies aren’t supposed to make you feel better. They’re supposed to make the other person feel better.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: In order to make you feel better.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Fine. You want to do an LP to confirm or is guilt enough to start filling prescriptions.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Last mass about a centimeter to your right.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Problem?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: A short burst of flutter. We’re almost done.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Entering the right hepatic vein. Cameron kept her dead husband’s sperm.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She doesn’t like yours?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She likes his better. Or at least she wants to hang on to it in case mine is… unfaithful or something.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Wow.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Advancing two centimeters.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: You gotta let her do it. If you don’t, you’ll be stuck with her forever.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I want to be stuck with her forever.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: She married a dying guy. She has issues. You cannot leave her ever, for any reason because then you’re not just the guy who left her; you’re the guy who killed her kids. That’s not a good rhythm. Get out.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Narrow complex tachycardia. She’s gonna crash.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Liver biopsy was negative for cancer but the procedure sent her heart into a-fib.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We don’t know it was the biopsy that caused the heart problem. Maybe the heart caused the lungs to collapse.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Why is Wilson here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You were looking for cancer. I thought it would be helpful for

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We didn’t find cancer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes. Which you reported to me five seconds ago. Thought I’d let him finish his hors d’oeuvres before getting the bouncer to take care of him.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Until we regulate the heart we can’t get meaningful pictures so we can’t tell…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Metoprolol can correct irregular heart…

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tried it. Didn’t work. Is Cuddy making him oversee?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No!

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Heart’s too irregular for MRI. Other scans wouldn’t …

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Then you’re making him oversee your choices. You don’t trust yourself. Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wilson. Get out.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Are you sure?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Do I need your approval to throw you out? You happy now?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: There’s only times her heart’s going to be still for our pictures and that’s when she’s dead.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It’s not MS. Severe mental illness and Vicodin are all that’s left. Mental illness means you can no longer practice medicine. Vicodin means detox, which means pain for the rest of your life. Which means you can no longer practice medicine.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Are you saying we should kill her?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: If we stopped her heart we could get our pictures and then restart it.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: What if we can’t restart it?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then she stays dead.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We restart hearts all the time.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: It’ll take four minutes to MRI her entire heart.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And we only have three minutes until there’s brain damage. Sure about this?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’re gonna stop her heart so I can MRI it. I think it was her idea. Pneumonia was her idea and almost killed my patient.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Her?

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Ooops.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Kutner was secretly a woman. That’s why he killed himself. It’s Amber.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Your subconscious picked my dead girlfriend?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. The irrational part of my brain works like the rational part of yours. How about that.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It raises questions.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It answers questions.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Who cares? I’ve got competing ideas. They can’t both be right.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Everybody gets competing ideas. Everybody has doubts.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So is it regular radical, me radical or me out of my mind radical?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: It’s on the upper end of you radical. Do you have any alternative?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing that anyone in my head has come up with.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Then you’re as safe as you can be.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Great. You get the LP results back?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah. It’s a big shock. You don’t have MS. But while I had your blood sample, I checked your Vicodin levels. Way too high.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need the pills.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Not an argument. He knows that’s not an argument.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It could still be schizophrenia.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, if you’re on anti-psych meds, you’re not going to be able to practice.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I know.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’d prefer electroshock therapy to rehab?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’d prefer something that could actually work.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You’re rationalizing.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: No kidding.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I know that you’re afraid of the pain, but electoshock?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t give me the cancer voice, that overly earnest tone.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Heart attack, stroke, seizure, death or worse.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Worse? Double-death?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You live but you damage the only thing you care about. Your rational mind. I’ll make some calls.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: I’ll actually be dead?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Just your heart. Just for a little while.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: Hopefully.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I have an idea.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Stop having ideas.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Insulin shock.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yes. That’s marginally less dangerous than ECT. Puts you in a coma, could cause…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Could work.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: If you had psychosis, which you don’t.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve had no diarrhea, no sweating, no vomiting. None of the symptoms of Vicodin overdose.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah, except the “I see dead people” thing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ve been popping pills for years. I’ve only been seeing things for days. Something changed.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Vicodin addiction is still more likely.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: So, we’re no longer dealing in absolutes.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, I’ll be up in five minutes. Then we can talk about how you’d rather be in a coma than in rehab.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Actually, if you could be up here in two, that’d be really helpful.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Why?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Because I’m about to put myself into insulin shock.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Left atrium is fine.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Left coronary artery also fine. We’re almost at three minutes.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Keep going.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Chordae tendineae clear.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Right atrium is fine.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I got to start her back up.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We have some time.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’re over.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Right coronary artery is fine.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The three-minute threshold is a guideline.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She might have less. We have to stop.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: What’s that by the aorta?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I don’t see anything.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’m restarting her heart.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: That’s a shadow. Two centimeters…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re only scared because you know this is going to work.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: We’re over three minutes.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yes.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I need glucose in here!

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You could have died.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It worked. Where are my pants?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Are you sure?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: She’s been everywhere I’ve been for days. She’s not here, ergo…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: This was not the next rational step.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Now who’s being biased? You wanted me to detox as much as I wanted… Forgot how to do my zipper.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Any other neurological deficit?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You don’t seem to annoy me as usual. I’m not sure that’s a deficit. And, I’m all better.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Is she really gone?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Absolutely. I can feel myself repressing all kinds of icky things. I check out, don’t I? Damn.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: He didn’t see anything. He saw an artifact on the monitor.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It was a shadow on her heart.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: She’d already been technically dead for three minutes. I thought keeping her alive took precedence over prolonging the photo op.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Any brain damage?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No. And all tests indicate that…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Obviously had more time.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Best of luck.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I assume we can’t kill her again and take more pictures.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Uhhh. You’ll wanna check with Wilson?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Good one.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It’s something. A lesion.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Tumor? Scar tissue?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Could be an abscess infection. Explains why it’s invisible in the blood. It’s doing its damage behind closed doors, sealed off.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: See, the problem with speculation is you make a speck out of you and some guy named “Lation” which really doesn’t affect me at all.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We have to guess. It’s all we’ve got. We can’t do a biopsy. The last time we went into her heart she had a major cardiac event.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Which just leaves…

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What are you looking for?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I don’t know yet.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: The picture doesn’t change. She lies there in pain. He sits there, worried.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Nothing changes. I just had an epiphany. All by myself. Popped into my head out of nothing.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Care to share?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: He’s too devoted.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Too devoted? You think he feels guilty?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Right. I’m being cynical. People can care because they care, not because they cheated. Theoretically true. But gonorrhea fits better.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: No. No STDs. We tested her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Tested her blood.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: That is the test.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s not where her problem is. Gonorrhea disseminated to her heart. Got walled off in an abscess, it’d be invisible.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And it would look like a shadow.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No need to test her again when we can check Prince Charming. Once you confirm, cut the abscess out of her heart.

utterance.speaker: Molly
utterance.content: Here are your onion rings, extra well done.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank you, Molly. And another beer when you get the chance. I’m celebrating.

utterance.speaker: Molly
utterance.content: Alone?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank goodness. Don’t tell me, I was right.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Yep. Boyfriend has gonorrhea.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And everyone’s a winner.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He’s not too happy about it. He insists he’s never cheated, must have gotten it from her.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Don’t think so.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Timing would fit. He’s got no symptoms and she’s dying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Lying would fit too.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: He’s not hanging out in her room anymore. What does it matter? You were right. We’re prepping her for surgery.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I saw guilt in him. If he’s not actually guilty, then I wasn’t right. I was lucky.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: House, you made a brilliant deduction about her heart.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And if I was just lucky…

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Enjoy yourself, it’s later than you think. Enjoy yourself, while you’re still in the pink. The years go by as quickly as a wink. Enjoy yourself. Enjoy yourself. It’s later than you think.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Wilson. Come get me.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I know a nice facility outside Philly. I went to undergrad with one of the directors.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thanks.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: How many shirts do I need?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: They said three. They have laundry.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Like living with Mom again. Delightful.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It’s probably Foreman.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’s unavailable.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Tell him the infection’s made her septic. We can’t remove the abscess until we get her BP up and it’s not responding to fluids, it’s not…

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: He’s off the case.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Patient okay?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: Yeah.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: He’s lying.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why don’t I feel scared?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: I’d say you’re unaware of what you’re feeling at this moment.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I feel like crap. My life if falling apart, but I don’t feel scared. Not of the rehab, anyway.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: We’ve always been able to find a way to cheat.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: It won’t work.

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You want it to work this time.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Do we?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: House, it’s your only option.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: What do I do if my only option won’t work?

utterance.speaker: Wilson
utterance.content: You don’t give up.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Hmm. It’s either that or electroshock every six hours. Good night, Wilson.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What if we put her on a heart-lung machine?

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: She’s septic. We don’t need a heart-lung machine. We need a blood-vessel-holder-together machine.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We could try high-dose dopamine. It’s a vasoconstrictor. It’ll close the blood vessels so she won’t bleed out.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Her heart can’t take that much dopamine. It’ll explode.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: And, if we don’t use the dopamine, it’ll implode.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Is House really done?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: It sounded that way.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Dopamine it is.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s late and I’m tired. Can we get to the talking part of this conversation?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I quit.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Great. My nanny is off the clock at 7:30 so your week off, bigger desk, tighter nurses’ uniforms or whatever other stupid thing you’re about to demand is going to have to wait until…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You can go suckle the little bastard child who makes you feel good about yourself.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Screw you.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Don’t do this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’m hallucinating.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: From the Vicodin?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Ruled out everything else.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We can, uh, admit you through the ER under a pseudonym. No one has to…

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I’ll cheat, scam, find some way to keep using.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: These people know what they’re doing.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: These people don’t know me. You do.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: She’s not your keeper. She has no responsibility for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I need you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Let me call my baby sitter.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Blood pressure is 90 over 60.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: We know.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: I’m just saying it’s still 90 over 60. It’s holding.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Abscess is intact. It doesn’t look like any of the surrounding tissue is affected. She’s gonna be fine.

utterance.speaker: Nurse
utterance.content: Doctor!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We’ve got a problem.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Lie down. I’ll get you some tea.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Yeah. That’ll be better.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: You really think she hasn’t searched this place for your secret stash?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I already did this room and the bathroom and your bedroom. Where should I look, in the kitchen?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Coffee cup. On the top shelf.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: That was a test. I already did the kitchen.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Nicely played. She’ll think you’ve come clean and given her everything.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: There’s more.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Don’t. You’re hurting already. It’ll only get worse.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: House, you should tell me where it is now because you won’t have the will to tell me in two hours.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: My shoes in the closet.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: It’s like I don’t even know who you are anymore.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Okay. Hold my hand.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: Am I okay?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: We were able to successfully remove the abscess from your heart but the dopamine caused the blood vessels in your hands and feet to clamp shut. We need to amputate or the gangrene will spread. You’ll die.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: My feet?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: And your hands. I’m sorry.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: No. I’m a dancer.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The tissue can’t be saved.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: We know what House would do.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: House would have never woken her up to ask for consent. If you can’t live with the answer, don’t ask the question.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: You’re saying we should accept her decision.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Bold idea, I know.

utterance.speaker: Thirteen
utterance.content: Maybe we can get the boyfriend to convince her to do it.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Yeah. Boyfriends get everything they want.

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Forget it. The boyfriend doesn’t want to talk to her at all.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Where are you going?

utterance.speaker: Foreman
utterance.content: Home. The case is over.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: No, it’s not. Not until we come up with something that might work. It’s a shame that she might die because House has some personal crap to work through.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Technically, if she dies it’s because House has some personal crap to work through and we weren’t smart enough to get the answer without him.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: False alarm.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Drink this.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s your advice? Drink this?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: It’s ginger. It’ll ease the nausea.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You know what would calm the nausea? Vicodin. Marijuana. A coma.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: Now, don’t pretend you didn’t see it. I saw it, which means you saw it. Send her away.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Too bitter. I already have enough bitter.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’ll add some honey.

utterance.speaker: Amber
utterance.content: You’re pathetic. If you want the pill, just send her home. But you can’t because that would mean admitting defeat to her.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: No!

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No! No!

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: This isn’t going to work.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: It might work. That’s all we’re going for. Vasodilators can…

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Big jump from reopening to reanimating. I’m out of the ulnar. I’m not seeing any clearing. This won’t work.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: This probably won’t work.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: Radial artery’s really tight.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: Don’t go too fast. If it clots, she loses the hand.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: If it clots, she’s dead. I can’t believe it.

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: What?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: It might be working.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Can you stop? The breathing.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Air goes in. Air goes out.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Then use your nose.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re supposed to feel like crap. You’re doing great.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And after?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You come back to work.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: And what if I can’t?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Opioid dependency can make you think you have more pain than you really have. You’re going to be okay.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You’re telling me what I want to hear. With no evidence.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’m telling you what I believe to be true.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: With no evidence.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re hardly the most unbiased observer.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Neither are you. I’m your hospital’s biggest asset.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Is that why you think I’m here?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: That’s why you’re here. That’s why you’re lying to me about…

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I haven’t lied to you in 20 years.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Sure you have. Which means that you just said that because you want to tell me what you lied to me about twenty years ago.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You’re an ass.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Am I wrong?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I wasn’t in your endocrinology class.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: You sat next to me. I cheated off you in the midterm.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I audited your endocrinology class.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Why would you…?

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: Because I thought you were an interesting lunatic, even then. I’m not here protecting hospital property.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: We’re alone.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: We’ve been alone all night.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: No, I mean Amber. She’s gone.

utterance.speaker: Penelope
utterance.content: Where’s Jeremy?

utterance.speaker: Taub
utterance.content: He left. You okay?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: The surgery worked.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Congratulations.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I can’t do it. You have doubts.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: And you don’t?

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: No.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: Well, that’s… naïve. I want to spend the rest of my life with you. I love you. That’s how I feel right now. But I don’t… know.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I’ll wait until you do.

utterance.speaker: Cameron
utterance.content: I can’t know. No one knows.

utterance.speaker: Chase
utterance.content: I do.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: I’ll see you in later? I have some papers to push for you.

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: Thank you.

utterance.speaker: Cuddy
utterance.content: You want to kiss me, don’t you?

utterance.speaker: House
utterance.content: I always want to kiss you.
